text: hello so welcome to the webinar this is Perry clayon and this is Jeremy Utley glad to
be with you today so we're going to Dive Right In the topic for today is how to make
Innovation a reality in your work and the framing that we're going to use for the uh talk today is actually refuting
Four myths about innovating in the workplace we find that it's important before beginning to uh engage in the
practices of design to innovate in your workplace to have a right concept of what Innovation means and what it
requires so we're going to start by telling a few stories and talking about
some common myths that people hold about innovation in the
workplace so the myth are the lone Rogue it's an easy
sell the customer knows best and it's a lightning bolt so these might seem a little cryptic but we're going to go
through them one at a time and um tell you a case or a story about each one
from our work all right so the first example we
want to talk about and the first myth that we want to debunk is the myth of the lone Rogue or the the innovator in
isolation uh we see that many organizations believe that individuals are responsible for Innovation and that
individuals alone have the inspiration required to innovate and that's a myit
that we want to debunk we're going to do that by telling a quick story of a good friend of ours named Doug beets Doug is
an executive on the global design team at GE Healthcare and encountered us at
the dchool about 5 years ago uh Doug is responsible for Designing
many of the uh Imaging machines at GE Healthcare such as the
one that you see on your screen below uh Doug came to an executive program at Stanford where we taught many
of the principles of design thinking that we teach uh to Executive Education students and we asked a simple question
at the end of his class what do you plan to do when you go back home what simple
activity can you engage in to begin to innovate in your work and for Doug who designs medical
equipment his answer was he wanted to go visit hospitals and actually see people
engaging with his machines so Doug did and the the
hospital that he actually visited was a uh Children's Hospital just happened to be a children's hospital Doug had
recently won an award for designing a a Imaging machine that W International IND
industrial design award so he's very proud of the machine he went and spoke with several doctors and nurses and they
all told him what he already knew which was it was a great machine it had made great scans and uh it was the top of its
class technologically but while he was there and while he was speaking with some of the technicians uh one of the nurses
came in and said Doug I've got to ask you to leave for a moment we have a patient coming in and so Doug said he
stepped out in the hallway and as he did he um saw a young couple walking down
the hallway and there they were both holding the hands of a little girl about 6 years old he said that as they walking down
the hallway he noticed that the little girl was crying and she was uh saying I don't want to do it I don't want to go
I'm scared and her parents were saying as you might imagine you can do it you you can be brave you're you're going to
be strong um he said he NOS that she didn't have any hair so it's clear that she was undergoing some type of serious
uh treatment but he said he couldn't figure out what she was scared of and um and so
anyway he stepped out of the exam room and when they came in when they rounded the corner and the little girl saw the
machine that he was so proud of the machine that he had won so many awards for he said that she burst into tears
and was overwhelmed with fear and he watched all this unfold he watched her
unable to keep still which is very important for the equipment that he's designed um to the point that the uh the
doctors had to bring in an anesthesiologist to come in to sedate this little girl
as you can imagine it was a very traumatic experience certainly for Doug but even more for the family that he was
watching and uh certainly unhealthy for the little girl um he said that in that
moment he went from thinking that he was a huge success to to realizing that at least in this regard he had failed so a
user that he was designing for he said that he wasn't sure whether this case was an anomaly or was
straightforward and was um the typical case so he said he started asking doctors and nurses that he knew hey how
often does do uh do children have to be sedated how often are they scared and he said he learned roughly uh four out of
five kids roughly 80% of kids have to be sedated when they undergo a procedure in one of the machines that he designed and
he was floored by that statistic as I think any of us would be he was absolutely shocked that so many of the
of the patients that had to undergo procedure in one of his machines were so
scared that they couldn't keep still and had to be sedated he saw this as a major opportunity not only to improve kids
lives but also to improve the bottom line of the hospitals because it was a major throughput issue for hospitals
that have to um increase their Staffing and increase their time for a procedure
so we began to work on the problem and we're going to cut right to the chase to show what he designed but over the
course of um engaging with these kinds of users he realized that what kids
really needed in their lives was adventure and and whereas their brothers and sisters would go to sports camp and
would play um uh various Sports and uh and and spend time Outdoors because of
these kids um medical situation and illness they were unable to engage in the same kinds of activities and so Doug
and his team ended up designing what you see on your screen now which is a series of devices geared towards infusing
Adventure into the medical procedures they had to undertake there are over 20
such machines in hospitals around the around the US now it's still a pilot but
um what Doug and his team have uncovered is if they can bring Adventure into the lives of
children they can dramatically improve the experience for the child and also
dramatically improve the experience for the hospital in the 20 plus hospitals
where they've deployed this uh machine called The Adventure series they've
brought sedation rates down exponentially um one thing that's interesting to note
is this team has not innovated based on a better technology the the the product
is actually technologically exactly the same but what they've done is they've completely changed the experience of
kids and in so doing they've generated um millions of dollars of sales for GE
and um brought patient satisfaction levels up to over
90% um from previous load of in the single digits in addition many families have
reduced their trauma obviously and um many kids have had a completely new
experience of what it means to undergo a medical procedure like this the thing that we want to point out though is that
Doug was not alone Doug did not do this on his own in isolation inspired as a
single and innovator but rather he took our advice and he assembled a team of
diverse experts folks ranging from kindergarten teachers
and curators of Children's Museums and Child Life Specialists you see Doug's
team had previously only collaborated with itself a bunch of designers with expertise in industrial design and
mechanics and they never thought about bringing in Outsiders to actually bring a fresh perspective on into their team
and into their work and when Doug encountered a new challenge of trying to design for the Delight of children who
were in terminal illness situations he recognized that his team was woefully inadequate in terms of the
expertise that was resident on the team and so at our uh encouragement and instruction he brought on a radically
diverse set of collaborators to help him bring fresh eyes to the
problem he he jokes that the uh ge uh Personnel uh HR office called asking hey
why are we uh why why do we have kindergarten teachers on the payroll and why are we uh employing uh folks
from Children's Museums because they were unfamiliar with bringing in such a radically diverse team though what doug
experienced in bringing such a radically diverse team together is that the
diversity of perspectives allowed him and his team to see the problem in a fundamentally different way than they've
been able to see it before and what see we see time and time again at Stanford is that when organizations are uh
approached with a very difficult challenge which forces them to draw upon
expertise that's beyond the expertise of their team that forces them to collaborate outside of their neat
disciplinary boundaries oftentimes what's needed is a radically diverse team with a radically diverse skill
set and so loan innovators are not themselves able to sustain and deliver
breakthrough Innovations but rather they need to be complemented with diverse perspectives and skill sets in order to
deliver breakthrough Innovations so the um one more example
this was a we thought an important um topic and I think one of the things that sort of uh perpetuates about Innovation
is the story of the loone inventor um so this idea of diverse teams and sort of reveling in the diversity of the team
and different perspectives and we'll talk about how you make a team like that work in one of the other mths but for
now just one more quick example um Patagonia is a clothing company for those of you who don't know it um makes
Outdoor Clothing down jackets um uh fleece and wool and um terrific company
based in Southern California founded by the shinard family um Iman Melinda shinard um amazing history founded in
the 70s um gives back uh 1% of its profits for environmental causes and um
builds all its products as sustainably as possible um anyway what the years I was there in the early 2000s um working
with a great team uh we were challenged with starting um a surf product line and
the approach we took was was to use design process but but further to put together a diverse team and this diverse
team um was sort of gave an interesting um product breakthrough and I want to
tell the story just briefly um by putting Surfers together for those of you that are Surfers you might recognize
the picture here's it's upper right hand corner is Jerry Lopez is a famous um Surfer from the the 70s um but we also
had Surfers on the team that were um you know pros at the time and we had of
course um designers that that were going to design the clothing you know but the interesting thing is we put which is not
commonly done in in uh it sounds sounds very obvious but we put fabric designers the people that actually develop the
Fabrics on the team um and folks from operations and folks from sales and all
these perspectives mixed together um throve a a very unique breakthrough um
Patagonia produced a wet suit which in my mind is still one of the most Innovative wets suits on the market um
made with wool so traditionally wet suits are made of neoprene and this is a product made of
wool and it allows the wet suit to be dramatically lighter um antibacterial
and um all these terrific things about it and it came from this directly from this diverse team um I remember the the
fabric designer on the team early on um because he was in that early early
session of dreaming about what products could be for the surf line and dreaming about the changes that could be made um
he also was an expert in fabrics and very very early on um had the idea that
you know maybe we didn't have to use the Fabrics that were used by everybody else to make wet suits maybe we could try
some other ones so very early on in the development of the product line um this
diverse perspective was brought into the team and completely broke the mold for what a wet suit um could become so as a
result these are the the lightest and thinnest wet suits you can get and um
really gave patagon a chance to enter the market with something um dramatically different and a direct
result of a very diverse team working on it not the results of a a lone inventor
the fabric designer on his own would not have been successful without the team around him so with that moving on to the
next myth one of the myths um we want to debunk is um the fact that ination is an
easy sell I think that um far too often when um inventors tell their story it comes
off as it was easy I made this breakthrough and the world beat a path to my door um I'll tell you a personal
story here that I assure you that's not the case um when I was a graduate student here at Stanford um a student of
David Kelly's in product design uh at the end of your your degree you had to come up with an invention so I chose of
all things to um invent a new Snowshoe so traditionally here in the picture um
at that point in the early 90s snowshoes were were pretty much all wood and um Rawhide or nylon and very very heavy
very hard to use um snowshoeing was not a um a sport per se wasn't something you
really did um but I I actually got interested in it because I'd broken my leg in graduate school and couldn't ski
and decided to Snowshoe and I didn't have a great experience I decided to design a new pair of snowshoes and you
can see on the right what came of it was a you know aluminum and and um and
neoprene and and very very sort of high-tech stoo with a with a binding and
pleates and all these systems in it and it was very Innovative loads of patents all this great stuff um and it allowed
people to um to run in snowshoes allowed people to Back Country snowboard name
the company outet Snowshoe company um thought the logo the name was really cool you know decided to build all the
snowshoes um and certainly went out to the trail heads and got um loads of
people jazzed every weekend with these products um but I assure you at this point the world did not beat a path to
my door um I did not um make the cover of Fortune Magazine um it took many many
years but one of the critical things with with snow becoming a larger activity was getting um ski resorts to
allow it and getting the mountain areas that um people wanted and had access to in the winter to actually embrace snow
showing and um you know that you tell the story it's it's it's amazing to me in hindsight to
say it took um every bit of five years to convince the first um of the big ski
resorts to actually allow snow shoing on the mountain it was it was something they turned away they thought it was silly they thought it was going to cause
injuries they thought it was going to um slow down the revenues in other areas and Veil Associates was the first one to
allow snowshoeing um this is the the first map I kept um we eventually had lots of
skuas added over the years but it's something I I like to sort of use as an example of the persistence it takes um
this these innovators um to see their their Innovations to Market and make it happen and it's not an easy sell um it
was a um a long um effort to get snow shoing accepted and it wasn't a result
of that first inspiration of um a wood Snowshoe not having to be so heavy and so bulky and making a lighter one it was
a result of a an effort to to persistent effort to bring it to Market and tell the story over and over and over and
finally convince um in this case um a really big um operator to allow
Snowshoe and that's something that we actually hear time and time again as we talk with innovators it's very easy when
those of us who are observing uh breakthrough Innovations coming to Market uh and then hearing the stories
the stories told retrospectively often make things sound very simple and very easy and we're able to retrospectively
piece together a beautiful story arc that makes sense to those who are listening but the reality is when you're
looking forward in the face of uncertainty in the face of the unknown trying to bring something to bear in the
market which has never been done before all of the forces uh in the
market are against you and in many times even forces within your own organization are against you we joke that the
antibodies of the organization come out to attack anything that seems unfamiliar and anything that seems as if that might
threaten uh the existence and success of existing lines of business even in the example that we mentioned earlier of
Doug at GE he even had trouble convincing his organization that this
that the problem of children and being sedated in imaging machines was a problem worth working on he actually
started by collaborating with a partner hospital because the hospital experienced the problem even more
acutely than his own organization did and so time and time again we see that
true innovators people who are truly interested in disrupting the market have to be willing to have a thick skin have
to be willing to take a few arrows a few punches get a few black eyes and bloody noses but have to truly believe in what
they're trying to achieve and we talk about empathy and a deep concern for the customer as a way to build that passion
build that inspiration and fuel the momentum that's required to actually beat the odds inside of your
organization and out so at that will'll move to the third myth because there's a lot of talk about um listening to your
customer and the customer knows best and while we wholeheartedly agree that it's
important to empathize with your end customer and develop a deep understanding of their needs we actually
believe that it's a myth that the customer knows best that's a little counterintuitive so
we'll give a quick example uh that hopefully illustrates the point in the mid uh 80s proor and gamble um
owns folders coffee they still own folders coffee but in the mid 80s folders coffee was in a bit of an
identity crisis what uh they did a bunch of market research and basically um as
as we hear the story what came out of the market research is that they learned the coffee category has been declining
for 20 years um they heard that young people they talk to young people they did focus groups and their the direct quote in the
marketing report was young people will never drink coffee um folders talked to all their
customers and the only thing they found out was their customers are dying off and they believed and told the
executives of proor and gamble that there's no way to make money in this category that was a direct quote to the
to the board no way to make money in this category they obviously um did not see the tide
shifting right and shortly thereafter Howard Schultz and Starbucks um reinig
reinvigorated the marketplace and um reintroduced a new generation to coffee
and the joys and the pleasures of coffee um we think this is an interesting example because it's clear that
listening to your customer and believing exactly what your customer says is not always the best way to proceed and
because they approach the problem that way folders and many and many organizations like
folders um misook what their customers were saying for um for the truth and
they believe that their product was about a specific product and rather than being about an experience and they
defined coffee as a product that sat in someone's um Pantry rather than as an
experience that could be wholly redesigned wholly reimagined and could
become a completely new and fulfilling part of someone's life and we see that
time and time again that there's this subtle difference between um seeking out
understanding of your your customer and seeking direction from your customer we believe it's imperative that you seek
understanding from your customer but to take direction from your C customers can often Lead You astray so we want to talk
about that word especially empathy for a moment the word empathy uh the Webster
definition is here the intellectual identification with or vicarious experiencing of the feelings thoughts or
attitudes of another um this is something that we talked about much more extensively in our course uh in the
Innovation and Entrepreneurship certificate but we wanted to say a few words about empathy here just to
differentiate what it means between taking directions from your customer versus understanding your
customer we think it's very important to get beyond what your customer saying to understand what they're
feeling um oftentimes market research goes as far as to explain what someone says and compiles a lot of what people
say but rarely does it get into the emotions behind what they're saying and what we believe is it's imperative that
a great designer and great innovator actually infirm meaning from what's being stated by a
customer we seek to understand and to gain insights from empathizing with customers not to gain directives not to
gain Direction but to gain Insight that's actually actionable for the team it's still the job of the design team to
innovate it's not the job of the customer to innovate Henry Ford famously said if I had asked my customers what
they wanted they would have set a faster horse we've all heard that quote and yet again and again and again we make the
mistake of asking our customers what they want just because we shouldn't ask our customers what they want doesn't
mean we shouldn't ask them what they feel though and what we um encourage
folks to do is to gain a deep understanding of your customers and your users needs so that you might actually
gain a level of insight that allows you and inspires you to do something they could never have imagined to
do we think about this insight as being a combination of observation and
inference observations are very important right we actually do need to go into the marketplace observe our
customers ask them good questions ask them what but just as important is the
other part of this which is making inferences based on our own objective
experience expertise and uses ourselves so that we might ask the question why and dig deep
into making inferences and understanding why this is something that our uh uh late colleague and predecessor Bill mrid
pioneered and understanding that insights must go beyond observations it isn't enough for folders just to ask
young people if they'll drink coffee that's not just enough to ask how much longer do we think our existing
customers are going to live what we have to do is go way deep more deeply into
understanding the social behaviors and patterns of a new generation to understand the need for connection the
need for uh identity the need for a place to connect that's outside of working home and leveraging those
insights we can redefine and reframe the opportunity space for our organizations and for our products in a way that we
can't if we just ask for directions from our customers one way that we do this is a
simple tool again we go through this tool in much more depth in our course
but um wanted to at least expose folks to this but it's a simple tool um as a way to think about um unpacking
observations from our users this uh this tool we call a user empathy map but it's a a four quadrant diagram on the left
there's specific observable behaviors and statements that our users make and
if you think about going out into the into um your place of work your place of business out into the wild so to speak
out into the field to observe your customers and your users in their day-to-day lives you can think about um
bucketing what people say and what people do and actually cataloging and making notes about what people say what
people do but then just as importantly and something that we often Overlook is making inferences and jumping to the
right side of this diagram making inferences about what people think and what people feel often
times these are implicit rarely are they explicitly stated um usually they're guesses but they're educated guesses and
we don't make these guesses for the purpose of flippantly guessing or postulating but we believe in Rapid
cycles and rapidly iterating and as quickly as we can make guesses getting back in front of our users and customers
to confirm my hypothesis and it's only in this manner of making observations
and then um Shoring up those observations with inferences that we can test um hypotheses that we can test
through prototypes through um unexpected interactions with our users that we can actually break through to unexpected
territory so I want to tell you um one more example with this myth and um want
to want to redeem the Proctor and gambles books we share the folders example um uh Proctor and Gamble is a a

they had plateaued they were flat as a business unit and um Claudia and her
team came in and and helped them and what they did was they went on visits um
to customers and they told customers we're going to come in we're from Proctor and Gamble um we'd like to know
how you use uh liquid cleaners we' like to interview you about
um how you clean your home and what you do and you know did a little bit of the empathy work that um Jeremy spoke of

something so over and over they would visit homes and um they observe something that the uh the customers

of their visit they had um a clean kitchen counter they had clean floors um
and then they went back and they asked a simple question they asked why why did you clean up and customers answered very

cleaners and pulling out an old traditional mop was kind of a drag and

over a billion dollar product at at Pro gamble the Swiffer which is a basically a in between pulling out the the mop and
filling a bucket and truly giving your for floor a full cleaning it's something else you can do with these liquid
cleaners that um Parton gal is so great at developing so a great example of an
observed behavior and an inference in sort of digging deeper with a customer they didn't come up and say what I want
is you know a a handle and a really really quick um cleaning you know they
didn't design the the product the Swiffer as you've seen it's it's basically a um a handle that has a a head on it that
you can attach um uh if you will almost like something like a little paper towel that's that's that already has the

them they got the Insight um by visiting the customers observing behavior and inferring from them um what they wanted
which was the ability to clean up around the house very very quickly um on demand
these little mini cleanups so with that we want to move on to the next uh myth of innovation uh the fact that um
Innovation is a lightning bolt too often we hear a story about a breakthrough moment and um the inventor tells the
story that this is the aha moment um we would actually tell you that's not the case that um Innovation is a process and
uh there's this is my favorite product story of all time the WD40 um those of you who don't know what w40 stands for
it stands for water displacement 40 and it's because was the 40th try at making
this lubricant this is a lubricant product it's sold um throughout the world um it's it's almost ubiquitous
it's it's a terrific product but the inventor took 40 tries to get there I think that's one of the myths of
innovation is um oftentimes when you tell a story about a breakthrough you tell the story only about that 40th try
um we would maintain um over and over and over if we dig into it uh it's a
result of um constant iteration and constant maybe maybe not lightning bolts
but Min Sparks along the way if you will little little breakthroughs that build up to that that big product or service
breakthrough um failing early and failing often this is a a great graph to look
at um about how it costs less to prototype early and cost less to try things early and fail early I would
maintain this is the graph though for for any breakthrough that um any great invention has gone through multiple
iterations multiple tries at that and it's it's little failures along the way
if you will it each one of these has a little spark too um that that maybe leads up to this idea that there's a big
breakthrough at the end of the big lightning bolt but the results of all these little mini tries along the way is
what Innovation process is about and the process we teach at Stanford we call
Design thinking is um a series of five steps um empathy Define id8 prototype
test empathize we spent a bit of time on with one of the myths of of getting deep with our our users figuring out what
emotions Drive their behavior figuring out what implicit needs they have and and developing some insights Define is a
is a way of um synthesizing all of that information about the customer developing a clear what we call a point
of view or a problem statement from that that's unique and usually reframes an area think of a Swiffer reframing
mopping to to these quick cleanups um id8 is a way of generate commonly one
of the key tools is brainstorming here um generating many many solutions are Innovation Potential from that problem
statement prototyping is when you you get real and you quickly quickly could very quickly build um these Concepts out
um low resolution prototyping is a Technique we really like to um see see our um students use so how fast can you
make something real is a is a key metric and then finally circling back with our user so just like the blue hex at the
beginning testing is about getting back with the user learning from those prototypes almost like probes to learn
more about your customer another way to think about this
is modulating between two different modalities one is focusing and the other
being flaring uh too many times in organizations what we see is that decision-making process and so-called
quote quote unquote Innovation processes are actually just the product of a long
funnel an Ever decreasing funnel and what we think is very important is for
teams to get explicit about having shared values around a process where you
oscillate actually between focusing at times intentionally focusing but then
also intentionally flaring at other times and we see that great teams do a good job of balancing those two
modalities but not only balancing them being explicit about which modality they in and recognizing that the modality
you're in determines the behaviors and tools you bring to bear on the process and the tools you bring to bear in order
to focus in order to make decisions are very different than the tools you bring to bear in order to generate options and
to create experiences and it's very important for Creative teams to get comfortable with and fluent with uh the
various tools that they have at their disposal when they're flaring and when they're focusing every step of the
process that Perry mentioned earlier has very specific tools that can be brought to bear and it's not so
important about a sequence in order so much as having a team shared understanding or social Covenant
if you will that there are times when we're going to bring certain tools to bear and there are other times when
we're going to explicitly not use those same tools argument is a great example criticism is a great example criticism
and argument are very helpful to make decisions they're very unhelpful when
generating options generating new ideas and being explicit about are we criticizing right now or are we not
criticizing right now on a team is critical because nothing shuts down new idea generation like criticism but if
the team isn't clear on when they're engaging what behaviors then we engage all behaviors at the same time and the
results is the same kinds of outputs that we always see one example we wanted to give quickly uh in closing is a
partner of ours from the class that we teach at the design school called D leadership Hiatt Hotel is a large Hotel
company over 500 hotels worldwide and what um we saw is as our students
engaged with haatt last year this is last January February um we saw that
consistency of process was able to bring a radically diverse team from Frontline
workers workers who are hourly employees um all the way up through management
ranks to folks from corporate headquarters who are coming in to work on the project consistency of process
allowed every everyone on the team to have to be able to immediately plug in and work together regardless of
hierarchy regardless of experience or exposure consistency of process enabled
the team to actually engage in the design process and avoid a lightning
bolt mentality because everyone with their diverse functional backgrounds with their diverse expertise and in the
organization history with hospitality everyone was brought to a Level Playing Field in terms of behaviors that were
acceptable for the team workpace by using a consistent process and we see this a great example of a radically
diverse team going back almost to the first bullet point debunking the myth of a lone Rogue it's important if you're
not a lone Rogue that you have a consistent process to engage consistent language that you use with a radically
diverse team so that you can be on the same page so that you can speak the same
language um but even more than process the thing that we'll wrap with and then we'll open it up for question answer is

Innovation and we'll close with these but these values um we find across all
kinds of Industries all kinds of functions in all different countries even that um that a focus on human
values is critical that a bias towards action as opposed to planning or as opposed to talking is critically
important this idea of showing not telling letting your work speak for itself embracing experimentation again as Perry
mentioned earlier with the graph um experimenting early seeking out failures early when they're cheap rather than
waiting to fail until it's really expensive radically collaborating as we've mentioned bringing in diverse
teams diverse backgrounds crafting Clarity from complexity not looking for simple answers from our customers but
rather um being willing to to to handle the messy inputs they give in crafting
clarity as a team and then lastly as we just mentioned and being mindful of process allowing uh a shared knowledge
of where we are a process to dictate what types of tools we bring to bear on
um on our given project what types of behaviors are acceptable on our team these shared mindsets on a team enable a
team to go way far beyond really reach escape velocity and break out of the
confines and box that they often times find themselves in in organizations and at this time I'm going

call the the um sort of the once you get outside of your target user group we
